page.title: 04BENENDEN WEALD, GEOLOGY
page.content: Through the centre of the area from north-west to south-east lies the Benenden fault which brings an anticline of Ashdown beds to the surface. To the north of this the area is mainly made of Wadhurst clay, while the southern part is mostly of Tunbridge Wells sandstone capped by Weald clay on the higher ground. This sounds as though there are great differences in rock type but the sands are interbedded with clays, and the clays with sands so that the distinction between the rock types is not obvious in the field. The relief is more marked where small streams draining via the Hexden Channel to the Rother cut deeply into the land producing steep wooded valleys.
